title: Trevor Story decides to stay with Red Sox, won’t opt out of contract
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Trevor Story will remain with the Red Sox, opting to play the final two years of his contract worth $55 million.
Story originally signed a six-year, $140 million contract in 2022 and played 157 games in 2025, his most with Boston.
With Story staying, Red Sox plan to adjust infield, possibly moving him to second base to accommodate Marcelo Mayer at short.

title: Marat Khusnutdinov keeps cashing in on his opportunities with Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Marat Khusnutdinov scored the winning goal in a shootout against the Islanders, contributing to Bruins' recent victories.
Promoted to a top-line role, Khusnutdinov has scored twice in the last three games, helping the Bruins win four consecutive matches.
Initially a fourth-line player, Khusnutdinov is gaining trust from coach Marco Sturm and playing alongside top scorer David Pastrnak.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Nov. 5)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Boston: 776 Boylston St. high-rise condo sold for $8,000,000, 2 bedrooms, 3 baths, built in 2008.
Allston: 42-44 Aldie St. two-family duplex sold for $1,600,000, featuring 6 bedrooms and 3 baths.
Acton: 16 Silver Hill Road Colonial home sold for $1,160,000, with 4 bedrooms on a 67,082-square-foot lot.

title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Rev. Miniard Culpepper wins District 7 seat over Said Ahmed after Tania Fernandes Anderson's resignation.
Henry Santana secures reelection for at-large Boston City Council seat, supported by Mayor Michelle Wu.
All incumbent Boston City Councilors, including Louijeune and Mejia, retain their seats in recent election.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Jake Wilson wins Somerville mayoral race with 11,185 votes, defeating Willie Burnley Jr. who received 9,054 votes.
Wilson campaigned on improving city services and addressing housing, street safety, and rodent issues in Somerville.
Former City Councilor Wilson's past roles include finance chair and president of Somerville Youth Soccer nonprofit.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police are investigating a fatal hit-and-run involving a pedestrian on Chelmsford Street on October 30.
A woman was struck and killed in the incident; police have located the vehicle but are seeking additional details.
Authorities request public assistance in the investigation, with tips to be directed to Lowell police at 978-937-3200.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Somerville voters approved a nonbinding measure to divest from companies supporting Israel's policies, with 55.7% voting in favor.
The Somerville for Palestine group led the initiative, overcoming legal challenges from Somerville United Against Discrimination.
The measure seeks Somerville's divestment from companies like HP and Lockheed Martin implicated in Israel's actions against Palestinians.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady cloned his deceased dog Lua into a new dog named Junie using a blood sample and biotech firm Colossal.
Brady invested in Colossal Biosciences, which partnered with Viagen, a leading animal cloning company founded in 2002.
Colossal aims to advance species preservation with cloning technologies, having recently acquired Viagen for their expertise.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu secured her second term unopposed, receiving 91.10% of the votes with 44% reported.
Wu's national profile grew after testifying to Congress about Boston's sanctuary policies against the Trump administration.
Wu implemented free bus lines in Dorchester and pushed for rent stabilization, maintaining 66% favorability in July.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu is set for a second term in Boston, running unopposed after winning the preliminary election.
Wu has focused on housing, affordability, and climate initiatives; housing costs remain a significant issue in Boston.
Residents are invited to suggest priorities for Wu's second term, focusing on housing, climate resilience, public safety, and more.
